thread.title: Top contenders for the 2015 Nobel Peace Prize
thread.title_full: Top contenders for the 2015 Nobel Peace Prize

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: Top contenders for the 2015 Nobel Peace Prize
text:
German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Pope Francis and a champion of rape victims are among oddsmakers' favorites to win this year's Nobel Peace Prize, which will be announced in Oslo, Norway, at 5 a.m. ET on Friday. Last year, the prize was awarded jointly to India's Kailash Satyarthi and Pakistan's Malala Yousafzai "for their struggle against the suppression of children and young people and for the right of all children to education."
USA TODAY
Nobel winner Malala urges kids to stand up for rights
Each year, there is no shortage of worthy candidates for the six-member Norwegian Nobel Committee to consider. An estimated 270 people have been nominated but the Nobel Institute is always secretive about the selection process.
Here are candidates that oddsmakers rate as favorites to win:
ANGELA MERKEL
German Chancellor Angela Merkel (Photo: Adam Berry, Getty Images)
Germany's chancellor has demonstrated moral leadership this year on a topic that few other government heads have tackled head on: opening her country's borders to up to 1 million refugees from conflict zones in Syria, Iraq, Eritrea and elsewhere. Not everyone in Germany supports Merkel's open-door policy and it remains to be seen how the country will absorb the huge influx of migrants.
MUSSIE ZERAI
Eritrean priest Mussie Zerai poses in front of Saint Peter's basilica on Oct. 4, 2015 in Vatican. (Photo: AFP/Getty Images)
Zerai, 40, an Eritrean Catholic priest, is the founder of an organization that has helped rescue migrants whose boats have encountered problems while trying to cross the Mediterranean Sea to reach Europe. He often takes calls in the middle of the night and relays GPS coordinates to the Italian coast guard.
POPE FRANCIS
Pope Francis waves to the faithful in St. Peter's Square at the Vatican on Oct. 3, 2015. (Photo: Riccardo De Luca, AP)
The pontiff has had a good year. He played a key role in helping to normalize U.S.-Cuba relations after more than a half century, encouraged a long-sought peace agreement between the Colombian government and a rebel group, and weighed in with calls for sensitivity and common action to deal with issues such as climate change, economic inequality, immigrants and homosexuality. Francis was among last year's favorites to win the prize. No pope has ever won.
DENIS MUKWEGE
Denis Mukwege, from the Democratic Republic of Congo, a gynecologist who specializes in treating victims of rape and extreme sexual violence, delivers a speech on Nov 26, 2014, at the European Parliament in Strasbourg. (Photo: AP)
The gynecologist from the Democratic Republic of Congo and colleagues have treated more than 30,000 rape victims, risking his life in the process. In 2012, gunman tried to murder him in his home. His name has been mentioned in association with the prize for several years.
JOHN KERRY/MOHAMMAD JAVAD ZARIF
Secretary of State Kerry poses with Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran Javad Zarif during a bilateral talk at the United Nations in New York on Sept. 26. (Photo: AFP/Getty Images)
Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart, Mohammad Zarif, are not favored by bookmakers, but there has been buzz for months that the historic nuclear deal they brokered in July should be recognized by the Nobel committee. Their intense diplomatic efforts over the past two years overcame many technical and political hurdles, as well as strong objections by Republicans in Congress and the Israeli government.
Below is a gallery of recent past winners of the Nobel Peace Prize.
2014-Malala Yousafzai, a Pakistani schoolgirl who stood up to the Taliban and defended her right to an education and Kailash Satyarthi won "for their struggle against the suppression of children and young people and for the right of all children to education" Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Fullscreen 2014-Kailash Satyarthi, an Indian children's rights activist and Malala Yousafzai "for their struggle against the suppression of children and young people and for the right of all children to education" Manish Swarup, AP Fullscreen 2011-Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, former President of Liberia, Leymah Gbowee, and Tawakkol Karman won "for their non-violent struggle for the safety of women and for women's rights to full participation in peace-building work" Paul Hackett, pool photo Fullscreen 2011-Tawakkol Karman, a Yemeni activist, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf and Leymah Gbowee won "for their non-violent struggle for the safety of women and for women's rights to full participation in peace-building work" Hani Mohammed, AP Fullscreen 2011-Leymah Gbowee, founder and president of the Gbowee Peace Foundation, Tawakkol Karman and Ellen Johnson Sirleaf won "for their non-violent struggle for the safety of women and for women's rights to full participation in peace-building work" John Moore, Getty Images Fullscreen 2010-Liu Xiaobo, a Chinese literary critic, writer, professor, and human rights activist won "for his long and non-violent struggle for fundamental human rights in China" AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen 2009-President Obama was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize "for his extraordinary efforts to strengthen international diplomacy and cooperation between peoples." Gerald Herbert, AP Fullscreen 2008-Martti Ahtisaari, former president of Finland won "for his important efforts, on several continents and over more than three decades, to resolve international conflicts" Martti Kainulainen, AP Fullscreen 2007-Former vice president Al Gore and the United Nations' top climate panel received the Nobel Peace Prize "for their efforts to build up and disseminate greater knowledge about man-made climate change, and to lay the foundations for the measures that are needed to counteract such change." Nicholas Roberts, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen 2006-Muhammad Yunus, a Bangladeshi social entrepreneur, banker, economist and civil society leader along with Grameen Bank won "for their efforts to create economic and social development from below" Pavel Rahman, AP Fullscreen 2005-Mohamed ElBaradei, chief of the International Atomic Energy Agency and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) won "for their efforts to prevent nuclear energy from being used for military purposes and to ensure that nuclear energy for peaceful purposes is used in the safest possible way"l Jean-Christophe Verhaegen, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen 2004-Wangari Muta Maathai, the first African women to win the prize "for her contribution to sustainable development, democracy and peace" Gurinder Osan, AP Fullscreen 2003-Shirin Ebadi, an Iranian human rights activist, won "for her efforts for democracy and human rights. She has focused especially on the struggle for the rights of women and children" Yves Logghe, AP Fullscreen 2002-Jimmy Carter, former President of the United States won "for his decades of untiring effort to find peaceful solutions to international conflicts, to advance democracy and human rights, and to promote economic and social development" H. Darr Beiser, USA TODAY Fullscreen 2001-Kofi Annan, a former U.N. Secretary General and the United Nations won "for their work for a better organized and more peaceful world" Charles Dharapak, AP Fullscreen 2000-Kim Dae-Jung, former president of South Korea won "for his work for democracy and human rights in South Korea and in East Asia in general, and for peace and reconciliation with North Korea in particular" AP Fullscreen 1998-John Hume, the former leader of the SDLP party of Northern Ireland and David Trimble won "for their efforts to find a peaceful solution to the conflict in Northern Ireland" Alastair Grant, AP Fullscreen 1998-David Trimble, a former leader of the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP) and John Hume won "for their efforts to find a peaceful solution to the conflict in Northern Ireland" Paul Mcerlane, AP Fullscreen 1997-Jody Williams and the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL) won "for their work for the banning and clearing of anti-personnel mines" Matthew Cavanaugh, AP Fullscreen 1996-East Timor Bishop Carlos Filipe Ximenes Belo and Jose Ramos-Horta won "for their work towards a just and peaceful solution to the conflict in East Timor" Muchtar Zakaria, AP Fullscreen 1996-Dr. Jose Ramos-Horta and Carlos Filipe Ximenes Belo won "for their work towards a just and peaceful solution to the conflict in East Timor" AP Fullscreen 1995-Joseph Rotblat, founder and president of the Pugwash Conferences on Science and World Affairs and the Pugwash Conferences on Science and World Affairs won "for their efforts to diminish the part played by nuclear arms in international politics and, in the longer run, to eliminate such arms" Jon Eeg, AP Fullscreen 1994-Yasser Arafat, Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres won "for their efforts to create peace in the Middle East" USA TODAY Fullscreen 1994-Yitzhak Rabin, Shimon Peres and Yasser Arafat won "for their efforts to create peace in the Middle East" Tim Clary, AFP Fullscreen 1994-Shimon Peres, Yasser Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin won "for their efforts to create peace in the Middle East" Malcolm Clarke, AP Fullscreen 1993-Nelson Mandela and F. W. de Klerk won "for their work for the peaceful termination of the apartheid regime, and for laying the foundations for a new democratic South Africa" David Brauchli, AP Fullscreen 1993-F. W. de Klerk, former president of South Africa and Nelson Mandela won "for their work for the peaceful termination of the apartheid regime, and for laying the foundations for a new democratic South Africa" Peter Dejong, AP Fullscreen 1992-Rigoberta Menchu Tum won "in recognition of her work for social justice and ethno-cultural reconciliation based on respect for the rights of indigenous peoples" Eric Risberg, AP Fullscreen 1991-Aung San Suu Kyi, former leader of the National League for Democracy (NLD) won "for her non-violent struggle for democracy and human rights" Charles Dharapak, AP Fullscreen 1990-Mikhail Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, won "for his leading role in the peace process which today characterizes important parts of the international community" Olga Shaly, AP Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide 2015 NOBEL PRIZES Where did the Nobel Prizes come from? | 01:11 Alfred Nobel amassed a great fortune when he patented dynamite in 1867. Worried about a legacy of destruction, Nobel's will established the Nobel Prizes upon his death. Nobel's will caused a lot of controversy both in Sweden and internationally. USA TODAY
1 of 9 2015 NOBEL PRIZES It's shockingly easy to be nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize | 01:19 What do Adolf Hitler, Rush Limbaugh and the co-founder of the Crips gang have in common? They were all nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize. Video provided by Newsy Newslook
2 of 9 2015 NOBEL PRIZES Swedish researcher co-winner of chemistry Nobel Prize | 01:08 Sweden's Tomas Lindahl, along with Paul Modrich of the United States and Aziz Sancar, a Turkish-American, has won the 2015 Nobel Chemistry Prize for work on how cells repair damaged DNA. Video provided by AFP Newslook
3 of 9 2015 NOBEL PRIZES Chapel Hill and Duke not rivals for Nobel Prize in Chemistry | 02:17 Duke University and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill are bitter sports rivals. But UNC's Dr. Aziz Sancar is sharing the Nobel Prize for chemistry with a Duke colleague whom he's been nominating for ten years. (Oct. 7) AP
4 of 9 2015 NOBEL PRIZES 2 Scientists in US, 1 in UK Win Chemistry Nobel | 00:38 Sweden's Tomas Lindahl, American Paul Modrich and U.S.-Turkish scientist Aziz Sancar won the Nobel Prize in chemistry on Wednesday for 'mechanistic studies of DNA repair.' Lindahl now works in Britain (Oct. 7) AP
5 of 9 2015 NOBEL PRIZES Nobel winners' findings on DNA could help fight cancer | 01:07 The 2015 Nobel Prize for Chemistry has been jointly awarded to Tomas Lindahl, Paul Modrich and Aziz Sancar for their work in mechanistic studies of DNA. USA TODAY
6 of 9 2015 NOBEL PRIZES US Scientist Shares Nobel Medicine Prize | 01:37 Dr. William Campbell, one of three scientists awarded the Nobel Prize in medicine on Monday, said he was shocked when he received the news. (Oct. 5) AP
7 of 9 2015 NOBEL PRIZES Nobel physics prize winners changed way we see world | 01:54 Takaaki Kajita of Japan and Arthur McDonald of Canada were awarded the 2015 Nobel Prize in Physics for their work on neutrinos, elementary particles that travel almost at the speed of light. VPC
8 of 9 2015 NOBEL PRIZES Nobel Prize in medicine honors research in parasites | 01:05 This 2015 Nobel Prize was awarded to Irish-born William Campbell, Satoshi Omura of Japan and China's Tu Youyou for discoveries that have helped doctors fight malaria and other parasitic infections. Tu is the first ever Chinese medicine laureate. USA TODAY
9 of 9 Last Video Next Video Where did the Nobel Prizes come from? It's shockingly easy to be nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize Swedish researcher co-winner of chemistry Nobel Prize Chapel Hill and Duke not rivals for Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2 Scientists in US, 1 in UK Win Chemistry Nobel Nobel winners' findings on DNA could help fight cancer US Scientist Shares Nobel Medicine Prize Nobel physics prize winners changed way we see world Nobel Prize in medicine honors research in parasites And here are all of the Americans who have been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
2009-President Obama was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize "for his extraordinary efforts to strengthen international diplomacy and cooperation between peoples." Jewel Samad, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen 2007-Former vice president Al Gore and the United Nations' top climate panel received the Nobel Peace Prize "for their efforts to build up and disseminate greater knowledge about man-made climate change, and to lay the foundations for the measures that are needed to counteract such change." Bjorn Sigurdson, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen 2002-Former president Jimmy Carter received the Nobel Peace Prize "for his decades of untiring effort to find peaceful solutions to international conflicts, to advance democracy and human rights, and to promote economic and social development." Bjorn Sigurdson, AP Fullscreen 1997-Jody Williams and the International Committee of the Red Cross won the Nobel Peace Prize "for their work for the banning and clearing of anti-personnel mines." Roar Vestad, AP Fullscreen 1986-Elie Wiesel won the Nobel Peace Prize for his role as chairman of The President's Commission on the Holocaust. Todd Plitt, USA TODAY Fullscreen 1985-Members of the Boston and London staff of the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War won the Nobel Peace Prize for, "authoritative information and by creating an awareness of the catastrophic consequences of atomic warfare." International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War Fullscreen 1973-Henry Kissinger won the Nobel Peace Prize for his role in the 1973 Paris agreement when he was U.S. secretary of State. He also served as assistant to the president (Nixon) for National Security Affairs. Michel Lipchitz, AP Fullscreen 1970-Norman Borlaug won the Nobel Peace Prize for his contributions to food production in Asia and Latin America. Jym Wilson, Gannett Fullscreen 1964-Martin Luther King Jr. won the Nobel Peace Prize as the "first person in the Western world to have shown us that a struggle can be waged without violence." AP Fullscreen 1962-Linus Pauling won the Nobel Peace Prize for campaigning against nuclear weapons testing. Paul Sakuma, AP Fullscreen 1953-George C. Marshall won the Nobel Peace Prize for originating the Marshall Plan. Library of Congress Fullscreen 1950-Ralph Bunche won the Nobel Peace Prize for his role as a mediator in Palestine. AP Fullscreen 1947-The American Friends Service Committee won the Nobel Peace Prize for "compassion for others and the desire to help them." American Friends Service Committee Fullscreen 1946-Emily Greene Balch won the Nobel Peace Prize for her work with the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom. AP Fullscreen 1946-John Raleigh Mott won the Nobel Peace Prize for his role as chairman of International Missionary Council and president of World Alliance of Young Men's Christian Associations. Library of Congress Fullscreen 1945-Cordell Hull won the Nobel Peace Prize for "his fight against isolationism at home, his efforts to create a peace bloc of states on the American continents, and his work for the United Nations Organization." Library of Congress Fullscreen 1931-Jane Addams won the Nobel Peace Prize for leading the Women's International League of Peace and Freedom. University of Illinois-Chicago Library Fullscreen 1931-Nicholas Murray Butler won the Nobel Peace Prize for promoting the Briand-Kellogg pact and for his work as the "leader of the more establishment-oriented part of the American peace movement." Library of Congress Fullscreen 1929 - Frank B. Kellogg won the Nobel Peace Prize for the Kellogg-Briand pact, an international agreement which signatory states promised not to use war to resolve "disputes or conflicts of whatever nature or of whatever origin they may be, which may arise among them." Library of Congress Fullscreen 1925-Vice President Charles G. Dawes won the Nobel Peace Prize for the Dawes Plan, which arranged for German reparations after World War I. Library of Congress Fullscreen 1919- President Woodrow Wilson won the Nobel Peace Prize for his role in establishing the League of Nations. Library of Congress Fullscreen 1912 - Elihu Root won the Nobel Peace Prize for "his strong interest in international arbitration and for his plan for a world court." Library of Congress Fullscreen 1906 - President Theodore Roosevelt won the Nobel Peace Prize for "his successful mediation to end the Russo-Japanese war." AP Fullscreen Like this topic?
